Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(t) \\) defined in the complex plane which is governed by \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i \\omega z \\), where \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit and \\( \\omega \\) a real constant. We examine the effect of a transformation \\( h(z) = e^{\\alpha t}z \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is a constant, on this function over time t.

If \\( h(z) \\) is applied to the function \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i \\omega z \\) without any further changes, will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was simply evolved up to t = T under \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i \\omega z \\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\( h(z) = e^{\\alpha t}z \\) alters the original amplitude of \\( z_0 \\) by a factor of \\( e^{\\alpha T} \\). This results in a different trajectory and endpoint because the amplitude growth introduced by \\( \\alpha \\) modifies how \\( z(t) \\) evolves from its initial state.
